critique: This executive order, issued during World War II, establishes an Alaska War Council to coordinate federal civil activities with military requirements. It aims to promote the safety of Alaskan citizens and facilitate the President's powers as Commander-in-Chief. The order emphasizes cooperation between civilian and military authorities in Alaska. It is difficult to assess the ideological tilt of the document. It does not directly address immigration. It expands executive power during wartime. It centralizes authority in the federal government. It prioritizes national security. It involves the government in economic matters to support the war effort. It does not directly address social inclusion.
